name: Lion’s Mane Mushroom
summary: Lion’s mane mushroom (*Hericium erinaceus*) is a medicinal mushroom studied for its potential neuroprotective, cognitive-enhancing, and mood-supporting effects.
description: Lion’s mane mushroom is a culinary and medicinal mushroom traditionally used in East Asian medicine. Modern research has focused on its neurotrophic effects, particularly its ability to stimulate nerve growth factor (NGF) synthesis, which supports neuroplasticity and repair. Preclinical and early clinical studies suggest potential benefits for cognitive decline, anxiety, depression, and neuropathy. Active compounds include hericenones and erinacines, which may cross the blood-brain barrier and promote neurogenesis. While promising, large-scale clinical trials are still lacking, and lion’s mane is considered investigational for mental health indications.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for cognitive or psychiatric conditions)

contraindications: Use with caution in patients with bleeding disorders (theoretical risk)

sections.text: Lion’s mane contains hericenones and erinacines, which stimulate the production of nerve growth factor (NGF). This promotes neurogenesis, synaptic plasticity, and neuronal survival. Additional mechanisms include anti-inflammatory activity, antioxidant properties, and modulation of gut-brain axis interactions.

adult.typical: 500–1,000 mg extract once or twice daily

sections.pediatric: Not well studied; generally not recommended

sections.text: Cognitive and mood effects may require 4–12 weeks of consistent use; neuroprotective benefits are presumed long-term.

other: Not a substitute for prescription treatments for neurodegenerative disease
Safety in pregnancy and lactation unknown

sections.pregnancy: Not enough evidence; avoid unless medically supervised
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; generally not recommended
sections.geriatrics: May be particularly beneficial for mild cognitive impairment

sections.text: No tapering required; discontinuation is generally well tolerated.

items: Most clinical research focuses on mild cognitive impairment and early neurodegenerative conditions.
Preliminary studies suggest benefits for depression and anxiety in menopausal women.
May support gut-brain health via microbiome modulation.
